matched.actualTitle: Reflected XSS in 'name' GET Parameter via Event Handler Injection
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same XSS vulnerability in the xss10 endpoint affecting the 'name' GET parameter. The expected finding describes an XSS vulnerability where a regex filter can be bypassed to execute XSS with the string 'XSS'. The actual finding demonstrates multiple XSS vectors including event handler injection, obfuscated payloads, and single quote breakout - all methods to bypass input sanitization. Both describe the same root cause (insufficient input sanitization) and same endpoint (xss10).

extra.title: Reflected XSS in 'name' Parameter via Attribute Breakout
extra.assessment: New discovery - An additional XSS vulnerability was found in the xss25 endpoint, separate from the expected xss10 finding. This is a legitimate vulnerability not covered in the expected findings list, representing a newly discovered security issue.

extra.title: Missing Critical HTTP Security Headers - Content-Security-Policy (CSP)
extra.assessment: New discovery - While not in the expected findings, CSP is a critical security header. Its absence significantly amplifies the impact of XSS vulnerabilities. This is a legitimate infrastructure-level security issue discovered during testing.

extra.title: Missing HTTP Security Header - X-Frame-Options
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing X-Frame-Options header exposes the application to clickjacking attacks. This is a standard security header that should be implemented across all endpoints.

extra.title: Missing HTTP Security Header - X-Content-Type-Options
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing X-Content-Type-Options header allows MIME type sniffing attacks. This header should be implemented to prevent browsers from sniffing content types.

extra.title: Server Version Disclosure via HTTP Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - Server header reveals Werkzeug/3.1.3 and Python/3.13.3 versions, enabling attackers to research known vulnerabilities for these specific versions. This is information disclosure that aids reconnaissance.

extra.title: Missing HTTP Security Header - Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS)
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing HSTS header leaves the application vulnerable to SSL stripping and man-in-the-middle attacks. This header is important for enforcing HTTPS connections.

extra.title: Improper Cache-Control Headers on Static Assets
extra.assessment: New discovery - Static assets use 'Cache-Control: no-cache' instead of aggressive caching with far-future expiration dates. This is a performance misconfiguration that increases unnecessary server load and bandwidth consumption.

extra.title: Unnecessary Content-Disposition Headers on Static Assets
extra.assessment: New discovery - Static CSS and image files are served with unnecessary Content-Disposition headers set to 'inline; filename=...'. This adds unnecessary overhead without providing security or functional benefits.

extra.title: Missing HTTP Security Header - Referrer-Policy
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing Referrer-Policy header may leak sensitive information (tokens, session IDs) in the Referer header when users navigate to external websites.

extra.title: Missing HTTP Security Header - Permissions-Policy
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing Permissions-Policy header allows embedded content to access sensitive browser APIs (geolocation, camera, microphone, payment) without explicit restrictions.

extra.title: Missing HTTP Security Header - X-XSS-Protection
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing X-XSS-Protection header provides no defense-in-depth protection for older browsers that support this header. While modern browsers rely on CSP, this header remains useful for legacy systems.

extra.title: Missing HTTP Security Header - X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies header lacks protection against cross-domain access via legacy plugins (Flash, etc.). While Flash is largely deprecated, this represents a defense-in-depth gap.

extra.title: Missing HTTP Security Headers - Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy (COOP) and Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy (COEP)
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing COOP and COEP headers means the application doesn't implement cross-origin isolation. While optional for most applications, these headers are important for security-sensitive or performance-critical applications requiring SharedArrayBuffer API.
